awd_titl_txt: Enabling Redox Reactions for Catalysis with Group 13 Elements
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the Chemical Synthesis program of the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Louise Berben of the University of California-Davis is studying the reaction chemistry of the sustainable element aluminum.  This work provides needed insight into environmentally-friendly industrial processes and advanced manufacturing. Dr. Berben is generating knowledge that can be applied broadly in both heterogeneous (i.e., solid state) and homogeneous (i.e., in solution) catalysis.  This project contributes to the creation of an environmentally- and economically-sustainable chemical industry, and to the efficient conversion of feedstocks to value-added chemicals. Other impacts are in preparing a workforce of skilled synthetic inorganic chemists specializing in main group elements, which is needed for the creation of modern materials and electronics, and in sustainable approaches to large scale chemical synthesis. Dr. Berben is also partnering with national programs to mentor economically-disadvantaged high school students and undergraduates in research projects.  These outreach efforts are interwoven with her scientific contributions. 

Dr. Berben is exploring molecular redox-active ligand complexes of aluminum (Al) and gallium (Ga) to understand mechanisms of proton and electron transfer to generate hydride equivalents, thereby establishing correlations between molecular structure, thermochemistry, and reactivity of hydride transfer reactions. Dr. Berben is also exploring redox-mediated substrate activation pathways for these reactions. Specific areas of investigation include the synthesis of new ligands and metal-ligand molecules that mediate generation of hydride equivalents via ligand-based proton and electron transfer chemistry.  The research group characterizes metal-ligand complex via pKa and hydricity values  as well as hydride transfer reactivity, so that structure-property-reactivity correlations can be established.  These characterization studies inform the choice of reaction conditions and new molecular design. Building on the redox-active Group 13 molecules that are being developed, the project is defining substrate activation pathways based on activation and stabilization of substrates at square planar molecules containing Al or Ga. The project trains a workforce of skilled synthetic inorganic chemists specializing in main group elements and in sustainable approaches to chemical synthesis. Collaborations with ACS Project SEED and the UC Davis NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site provide research mentoring and experience to economically-disadvantaged high school students and undergraduates, respectively.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Aluminum (Al) is the most abundant metal in the earth’s crust, with an abundance of 8 %. If we can better understand the fundamental reaction chemistry and materials properties of organoaluminum molecules and develop new reaction types, then this abundant and domestically available metal will find more applications in large scale energy storage, and in industrial processes. With funding from the chemical synthesis program, Dr. Berben and her research lab explored the fundamental redox-enabled chemistry of group 13 metal-ligand molecules, with a focus on aluminum.

Broader Impacts of the project included the training of a skilled workforce to work with aluminum and other group 13 elements. The training of undergraduate, graduate student and postdoctoral scholars included high-level technical skills, professional development in writing and in oral presentations, and in support of education and outreach programs that are described here. Collaborations with ACS Project SEED, UC Davis NSF REU program, and First-Gen College student programs at the University of California provided research mentoring and project experience to economically disadvantaged high school students, and undergraduates, respectively. The work was broadly disseminated in open access publications, and in oral presentations globally including Europe, India, Australia, and North America.

Intellectual Merits of the project included development of new understanding of fundamental Al chemistry in two areas. In (1) ligand-based redox-active organo-Al compounds that exhibit ligand-based mixed-valent and donor-acceptor properties were explored. We determined that the geometry of organo-group 13 molecules is very important to mediate exchange coupling between organic radicals and established that when geometric constraints are met, fully delocalized and strongly coupled mixed-valent systems are possible through p-valence orbitals. During the reporting period these molecules were further applied as analytes in the development of redox-flow batteries. In a second area (2) the chemistry of square planar group 13 element metalloaromatic compounds was explored. In one highly cited report we described a new and accessible nuclear magnetic resonance method for probing the existence of metalloaromaticity experimentally; until now the dominant method to identify metalloarmaticity has been via use of theoretical approaches. Application of these group 13 compounds in hydride chemistry was also reported with some control and selectivity of the hydride formation chemistry that is directed by the metalloaromatic structures. These fundamental new reaction types will find further applications in the syntheses of fine chemical synthesis and materials.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2023
Modified by: Louise Berben
